title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Summary tables with janitor
tabyl() in the janitor package makes frequency tables much easier than base R.




One-way frequency table

nhanes.samp.adult %>%
  tabyl(Gender)

 Gender  n   percent
 female 70 0.5185185
   male 65 0.4814815


Gives you counts (n), percentages (percent), and includes missing values automatically.

Two-way table (cross-tabulation)

nhanes.samp.adult %>%
  tabyl(Gender, Diabetes)

 Gender No Yes
 female 62   8
   male 60   5

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
section: Enhancing tables with janitor adorn functions
text:
Enhancing tables with janitor adorn functions
janitor has ‚Äúadorn‚Äù functions to format tables nicely.




Add percentages

nhanes.samp.adult %>%
  tabyl(Gender, Diabetes) %>%
  adorn_percentages("row") %>%
  adorn_pct_formatting(digits = 1)

 Gender    No   Yes
 female 88.6% 11.4%
   male 92.3%  7.7%



Add totals

nhanes.samp.adult %>%
  tabyl(Gender, Diabetes) %>%
  adorn_totals(c("row", "col"))

 Gender  No Yes Total
 female  62   8    70
   male  60   5    65
  Total 122  13   135

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Combining adorn functions
You can chain multiple adorn functions together.

nhanes.samp.adult %>%
  tabyl(Gender, Diabetes) %>%
  adorn_totals(c("row", "col")) %>%
  adorn_percentages("row") %>%
  adorn_pct_formatting(digits = 1) %>%
  adorn_ns()

 Gender          No        Yes        Total
 female 88.6%  (62) 11.4%  (8) 100.0%  (70)
   male 92.3%  (60)  7.7%  (5) 100.0%  (65)
  Total 90.4% (122)  9.6% (13) 100.0% (135)





adorn_ns() adds the counts alongside percentages
Order matters: calculate totals first, then percentages

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Data visualization with ggplot2

Artwork by @allison_horst

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Why visualize data?
Visualizations help us:

Understand distributions
Identify outliers and patterns
Compare groups
Communicate findings

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Anscombe‚Äôs Quartet
Four datasets with identical summary statistics but very different patterns:

All four have the same mean, SD, and correlation - but look how different they are!

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
The Datasaurus Dozen
Similar to Anscombe‚Äôs quartet, The Datasaurus Dozen is a compilation of 13 data sets with similar numerical summaries and radically different visual summaries. See a great discussion of this dataset by the creators, Justin Matejka and George Fitzmaurice here

All 13 datasets have nearly identical summary statistics: Mean X = 54.3, Y = 47.8 SD X = 16.77, Y = 26.94 Cor = -0.06

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
The grammar of graphics
ggplot2 implements the grammar of graphics - a framework for describing plots.


Every ggplot has three essential components:

Data - the dataset you‚Äôre plotting
Aesthetics (aes()) - mappings from data to visual properties (x, y, color, size, etc.)
Geoms - geometric objects that represent the data (points, lines, bars, etc.)



Basic template:

ggplot(data = DATA, 
       mapping = aes(x = X_VAR, y = Y_VAR)) +
  geom_SOMETHING()



Notice we use + (not %>%) to add layers to a ggplot.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text: Basics of a ggplot

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Grammar of ggplot2








Beyond the basics:

Scales control how data values map to visual properties
Facets create subplots
Coordinates adjust the coordinate system
Themes control visual appearance

Most of these have good defaults - we‚Äôll focus on the essential three components today.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
section: Building a ggplot step by step
text:
Building a ggplot step by step
Step 1: Just data

ggplot(data = nhanes.samp.adult)

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
section: Building a ggplot step by step
text:
Building a ggplot step by step
Step 2: Add mapping

ggplot(nhanes.samp.adult, aes(x = BMI))

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
section: Building a ggplot step by step
text:
Building a ggplot step by step
Step 3: Add geom

ggplot(nhanes.samp.adult, aes(x = BMI)) +
  geom_histogram()

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Your first ggplot: histogram
Histogram - shows the distribution of a single numeric variable.


ggplot(data = nhanes.samp.adult, 
       mapping = aes(x = BMI)) +
  geom_histogram()











What does this tell us?

Most people have BMI between 20-35
Distribution is slightly right-skewed
Some people with very high BMI (outliers)

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Customizing histograms
You can control the appearance of histograms.




Adjust bin width

ggplot(nhanes.samp.adult, 
       aes(x = BMI)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 2)









Adjust number of bins

ggplot(nhanes.samp.adult, 
       aes(x = BMI)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 50)









Try different values to find what best reveals patterns in your data.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Boxplots - comparing distributions
Boxplot - shows the distribution across groups.


ggplot(nhanes.samp.adult, 
       aes(x = Gender, y = BMI)) +
  geom_boxplot()











Boxplot components:

Box: middle 50% of data (IQR)
Line in box: median
Whiskers: extend to most extreme non-outlier values
Points: potential outliers

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Boxplot by multiple groups
We can compare distributions across multiple categorical variables.


ggplot(nhanes.samp.adult, 
       aes(x = Diabetes, y = BMI)) +
  geom_boxplot()











People with diabetes tend to have higher BMI.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Adding color to boxplots
Color can be mapped to a variable using aes().


ggplot(nhanes.samp.adult, 
       aes(x = Gender, 
           y = BMI, 
           fill = Diabetes)) +
  geom_boxplot()











fill controls the fill color of shapes.
color would control the outline color.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
section: Scatterplots - relationship between two numeric variables
text:
Scatterplots - relationship between two numeric variables
Scatterplot - shows the relationship between two numeric variables.


ggplot(nhanes.samp.adult, 
       aes(x = Height, y = Weight)) +
  geom_point()











What we see:

Positive relationship
Taller people tend to weigh more
Some variability

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Enhancing scatterplots with color
Map a third variable to color to see patterns.


ggplot(nhanes.samp.adult, 
       aes(x = Height, 
           y = Weight, 
           color = Gender)) +
  geom_point()











Now we can see if the relationship differs by gender.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Adjusting point transparency
When points overlap, transparency (alpha) helps.


ggplot(nhanes.samp.adult, 
       aes(x = Height, 
           y = Weight, 
           color = Gender)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5)











alpha ranges from 0 (transparent) to 1 (opaque).

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Bar charts - categorical data
Bar chart - shows counts or frequencies of categories.


ggplot(nhanes.samp.adult, 
       aes(x = Diabetes)) +
  geom_bar()











geom_bar() automatically counts observations in each category.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Grouped bar charts
Compare categories across groups by mapping a variable to fill.


ggplot(nhanes.samp.adult, 
       aes(x = Gender, 
           fill = Diabetes)) +
  geom_bar()











By default, bars are stacked.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Position adjustments for bar charts


Stacked (default)

ggplot(nhanes.samp.adult, 
       aes(x = Gender, 
           fill = Diabetes)) +
  geom_bar()









Side-by-side

ggplot(nhanes.samp.adult, 
       aes(x = Gender, 
           fill = Diabetes)) +
  geom_bar(position = "dodge")

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Adding labels and titles
Make your plots more informative with labels.


ggplot(nhanes.samp.adult, 
       aes(x = Height, y = Weight)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  labs(
    title = "Height vs Weight in NHANES",
    subtitle = "Adult participants",
    x = "Height (cm)",
    y = "Weight (kg)",
    caption = "Data: NHANES"
  )

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Faceting - small multiples
Facets create separate panels for subgroups.


ggplot(nhanes.samp.adult, 
       aes(x = BMI)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 30) +
  facet_wrap(~Gender)











facet_wrap() creates a panel for each level of a variable.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Faceting by two variables
Create a grid of panels with two variables.


ggplot(nhanes.samp.adult, 
       aes(x = BMI)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 30) +
  facet_grid(Gender ~ Diabetes)











facet_grid() creates rows √ó columns layout.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Combining dplyr and ggplot2
You can pipe data directly into ggplot()!


nhanes.samp.adult %>%
  filter(Age >= 50) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Height, y = Weight)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  labs(title = "Height vs Weight (Age ‚â• 50)")











Pipe %>% passes data to ggplot().
Then use + to add layers.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Saving your work
Remember: dplyr operations don‚Äôt modify the original data unless you save them.




Save filtered data

adults_diabetes <- nhanes.samp.adult %>%
  filter(Diabetes == "Yes")

# Check it worked
nrow(adults_diabetes)

[1] 13



Save data with new variables

nhanes_with_categories <- 
  nhanes.samp.adult %>%
  mutate(
    bmi_category = case_when(
      BMI < 18.5 ~ "Underweight",
      BMI < 25 ~ "Normal",
      BMI < 30 ~ "Overweight",
      BMI >= 30 ~ "Obese"
    )
  )

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Saving plots
Save plots to files with ggsave().

# Create a plot
p <- ggplot(nhanes.samp.adult, aes(x = BMI)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 30) +
  labs(title = "Distribution of BMI")

# Save it
ggsave("bmi_histogram.png", plot = p, 
       width = 8, height = 6, dpi = 300)



Tips:

ggsave() saves the last plot if you don‚Äôt specify plot =
Common formats: .png, .pdf, .jpg
Adjust width and height in inches
Use dpi = 300 for publication quality

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Common ggplot2 geoms








Geom
Use case
Variables needed




geom_histogram()
Distribution of one numeric variable
x


geom_density()
Smooth distribution curve
x


geom_boxplot()
Compare distributions across groups
x (categorical), y (numeric)


geom_point()
Relationship between two numeric variables
x, y


geom_line()
Trends over time or ordered data
x, y


geom_bar()
Counts of categorical data
x


geom_col()
Pre-computed values
x, y

text:
Quick practice: solution

ggplot(nhanes.samp.adult, 
       aes(x = Age, y = BMI, color = Diabetes)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  labs(
    title = "Relationship between Age and BMI",

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
EDA workflow summary
1. Import and inspect

Load data
Check dimensions, variable names, and types
Look for missing values

2. Summarize

Calculate summary statistics
Create frequency tables
Group by relevant variables

3. Visualize

Plot distributions (histograms, boxplots)
Explore relationships (scatterplots)
Compare groups (facets, colors)

4. Iterate

Ask new questions based on what you find
Filter, transform, and visualize again

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Data Visualization
text:
Key takeaways

Pipes (%>%) chain operations together for readable code
dplyr verbs manipulate data:

filter() - subset rows
select() - choose columns
mutate() - create/modify variables
group_by() + summarize() - calculate summaries by group

janitor::tabyl() creates clean frequency tables
rstatix::get_summary_stats() provides pipe-friendly summary statistics
ggplot2 builds visualizations using data + aesthetics + geoms
Nothing changes your original data unless you save it with <-

BMSC 620 | EDA + Data Viz

title: Bayes‚Äô Theorem
section: Recap: What we did last time
text:
Recap: What we did last time


Last class, we calculated the Positive Predictive Value (PPV) using a contingency table:






Disease
No Disease
Total




Test +
90
990
1,080


Test -
10
8,910
8,920


Total
100
9,900
10,000





\[P(\text{Disease} \mid \text{Test +}) = \frac{90}{1,080} \approx 0.083\]


Today we‚Äôll see the formula that lets us calculate this directly.

title: Bayes‚Äô Theorem
text:
The question we‚Äôre asking


We want to flip the conditional probability:




What we know:

\(P(\text{Test +} \mid \text{Disease})\) (sensitivity)
\(P(\text{Test +} \mid \text{No Disease})\) (1 - specificity)
\(P(\text{Disease})\) (prevalence)


What we want:

\(P(\text{Disease} \mid \text{Test +})\) (PPV)




Bayes‚Äô Theorem gives us a formula to ‚Äúflip‚Äù the conditional.

title: Bayes‚Äô Theorem
text:
Bayes‚Äô Theorem: General form


\[
P(A \mid B) = \frac{P(B \mid A) \times P(A)}{P(B)}
\]


In words:

\(P(A \mid B)\) = posterior (what we want to know)
\(P(B \mid A)\) = likelihood (what we can measure)
\(P(A)\) = prior (base rate)
\(P(B)\) = marginal probability of \(B\)

title: Bayes‚Äô Theorem
text:
Bayes‚Äô Theorem: Medical testing version


For our diagnostic test:
\[
P(\text{Disease} \mid \text{Test +}) = \frac{P(\text{Test +} \mid \text{Disease}) \times P(\text{Disease})}{P(\text{Test +})}
\]


In words:

\(P(\text{Disease} \mid \text{Test +})\) = PPV (what we want)
\(P(\text{Test +} \mid \text{Disease})\) = sensitivity (what test manufacturer tells us)
\(P(\text{Disease})\) = prevalence (base rate in population)
\(P(\text{Test +})\) = overall rate of positive tests

title: Bayes‚Äô Theorem
text:
The tricky part: \(P(\text{Test +})\)


How do we find \(P(\text{Test +})\)?


There are two ways to test positive:

Have disease AND test positive: \(P(\text{Disease and Test +})\)
No disease AND test positive: \(P(\text{No Disease and Test +})\)



Using the law of total probability:
\[
P(\text{Test +}) = P(\text{Test +} \mid \text{Disease}) \times P(\text{Disease}) + P(\text{Test +} \mid \text{No Disease}) \times P(\text{No Disease})
\]

title: Bayes‚Äô Theorem
text:
Bayes‚Äô Theorem: Complete formula


\[
P(\text{Disease} \mid \text{Test +}) = \frac{P(\text{Test +} \mid \text{Disease}) \times P(\text{Disease})}{P(\text{Test +} \mid \text{Disease}) \times P(\text{Disease}) + P(\text{Test +} \mid \text{No Disease}) \times P(\text{No Disease})}
\]


This looks complicated, but we have all the pieces!

title: Bayes‚Äô Theorem
section: Applying Bayes‚Äô Theorem to our example
text:
Applying Bayes‚Äô Theorem to our example


Given:

Sensitivity = 90% = \(P(\text{Test +} \mid \text{Disease}) = 0.90\)
Specificity = 90%, so \(P(\text{Test +} \mid \text{No Disease}) = 0.10\)
Prevalence = 1% = \(P(\text{Disease}) = 0.01\)
Therefore: \(P(\text{No Disease}) = 0.99\)

title: Bayes‚Äô Theorem
text:
Step 1: Calculate the numerator


\[
\begin{aligned}
\text{Numerator} &= P(\text{Test +} \mid \text{Disease}) \times P(\text{Disease}) \\
&= 0.90 \times 0.01 \\
&= 0.009
\end{aligned}
\]


This represents the true positives (people who have disease AND test positive).

title: Bayes‚Äô Theorem
text:
Step 2: Calculate the denominator


\[
\begin{aligned}
\text{Denominator} &= P(\text{Test +} \mid \text{Disease}) \times P(\text{Disease}) \\
&\quad + P(\text{Test +} \mid \text{No Disease}) \times P(\text{No Disease}) \\
&= (0.90 \times 0.01) + (0.10 \times 0.99) \\
&= 0.009 + 0.099 \\
&= 0.108
\end{aligned}
\]


This represents all positive tests (true positives + false positives).

title: Bayes‚Äô Theorem
text:
Step 3: Calculate PPV


\[
\begin{aligned}
P(\text{Disease} \mid \text{Test +}) &= \frac{0.009}{0.108} \\
&\approx 0.083 \\
&= 8.3\%
\end{aligned}
\]


Same answer as before! But now we calculated it directly from the formula.

title: Bayes‚Äô Theorem
text:
Connecting to the contingency table




Bayes‚Äô Theorem:
\[
\frac{0.90 \times 0.01}{(0.90 \times 0.01) + (0.10 \times 0.99)} = 0.083
\]


Numerator: true positives
Denominator: all positives

Contingency table:










Disease
No Disease
Total




Test +
90
990
1,080


Test -
10
8,910
8,920


Total
100
9,900
10,000





\[\frac{\textcolor{red}{90}}{\textcolor{purple}{1,080}} = 0.083\]



The formula gives us the proportions directly!

title: Bayes‚Äô Theorem
text:
Why is this useful?


Without Bayes‚Äô Theorem:

Build entire contingency table
Need to choose a population size
More steps, more chances for errors



With Bayes‚Äô Theorem:

Plug numbers directly into formula
Get answer immediately
Works with any probabilities (don‚Äôt need counts)



Both approaches work - use whichever makes more sense to you!

title: Bayes‚Äô Theorem
section: What to remember about Bayes‚Äô Theorem
text:
What to remember about Bayes‚Äô Theorem


The formula:
\[
P(A \mid B) = \frac{P(B \mid A) \times P(A)}{P(B)}
\]


Key concepts:

Bayes‚Äô Theorem ‚Äúflips‚Äù conditional probabilities
Always consider base rates (priors)
Low prevalence ‚Üí low PPV, even with accurate tests
Can use formula OR contingency table (both work!)
Posterior = (Likelihood √ó Prior) / Evidence

title: Bayes‚Äô Theorem
text:
Bayes vs.¬†Contingency tables




Contingency table approach:
Pros:

Visual and intuitive
See all relationships
Good for teaching

Cons:

Requires choosing population size
More steps
Can‚Äôt easily see effect of changing parameters


Bayes‚Äô Theorem approach:
Pros:

Direct calculation
Works with proportions
Easy to see how prevalence affects PPV

Cons:

Formula can seem abstract
Need to remember to calculate denominator




Use whichever approach makes more sense to you!



BMSC 620 | Bayes‚Äô Theorem

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of today‚Äôs class, you should be able to:

Define random variables and distinguish between discrete and continuous random variables
Calculate the expected value (mean) and variance of discrete random variables
Calculate the expected value and variance of linear combinations of random variables
Identify when the Binomial distribution is appropriate and calculate probabilities using it

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Roadmap for Today
Part 1: Random Variables (Section 3.1)

What are random variables?
Expected value and variance
Linear combinations of random variables

Part 2: Binomial Distribution (Section 3.2)

Bernoulli distribution
Binomial distribution
Calculating probabilities with the Binomial

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
section: Motivation: From Data to Probability Models
text:
Motivation: From Data to Probability Models
So far we‚Äôve worked with:

Data points: \(x_1, x_2, x_3, \ldots, x_n\) (observed values)
Sample statistics: mean, variance, standard deviation

Now we‚Äôre moving to:

Random variables: mathematical models for uncertain outcomes
Probability distributions: theoretical descriptions of random phenomena
Parameters: population-level quantities (like \(\mu\) and \(\sigma\))

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Random Variables vs Observed Data



Three related (but different) ideas



Random variable:
\(X\) = the random process before we observe anything
Observed data:
\(x_1, x_2, \dots, x_n\) = the numbers we actually observe
Probability distribution:
Describes how \(X\) behaves before data are collected




Key idea:
Data are realizations of a random variable, not the random variable itself.

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
What is a Random Variable?



Definition: Random Variable


A random variable (r.v.) assigns numerical values to the outcomes of a random phenomenon.



Notation:

We use capital letters like \(X\), \(Y\), \(Z\) for random variables
We use lowercase letters like \(x\), \(y\), \(z\) for specific values

Key idea: A random variable connects random outcomes to numbers and probabilities

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Example: Rolling a Die
Suppose you roll a fair 6-sided die. Let \(X\) be the outcome of the roll.
Question 1: What is the probability distribution of \(X\)?




\(x\)
1
2
3
4
5
6




\(P(X=x)\)
1/6
1/6
1/6
1/6
1/6
1/6





Note:

Each outcome has equal probability (fair die)
Probabilities sum to 1: \(\sum_{x=1}^6 P(X=x) = 1\)
All outcomes are disjoint (mutually exclusive)

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Probability Distributions: Quick Review



Rules for a Probability Distribution


A probability distribution must satisfy three rules:

The outcomes must be disjoint (mutually exclusive)
Each probability must be between 0 and 1
The probabilities must sum to 1




These are the same rules we learned in our probability unit!





Probability Distributions (Discrete)


For a discrete random variable, the probability mass function (pmf) is
\[
f(x) = P(X = x)
\]

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Discrete vs.¬†Continuous Random Variables





Discrete Random Variable


A discrete r.v. takes on:

A finite number of values, OR
A countably infinite number of values

Examples:

Number of heads in 10 coin flips
Number of students in a class
Number of COVID cases per day








Continuous Random Variable


A continuous r.v. can take:

Any real value in an interval
Any value in a union of intervals

Examples:

Height
Blood pressure
Time until an event occurs






Today‚Äôs focus: Discrete random variables (continuous coming soon!)

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Expected Value (Mean)
The expected value of a random variable is its long-run average value.



Definition: Expected Value of a Discrete R.V.


If \(X\) takes on outcomes \(x_1, \ldots, x_k\) with probabilities \(P(X=x_1), \ldots, P(X=x_k)\), then:
\[E(X) = \mu = \sum_{i=1}^k x_i \cdot P(X=x_i)\]
The expected value is a weighted average where weights are probabilities.



Notation: \(E(X)\) or \(\mu\) (mu)

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
section: Example: Expected Value of Rolling a Die
text:
Example: Expected Value of Rolling a Die
Question 2: What is the expected outcome when rolling a fair die?

\[\begin{aligned}
E(X) &= \sum_{x=1}^6 x \cdot P(X=x) \\
&= 1 \cdot \frac{1}{6} + 2 \cdot \frac{1}{6} + 3 \cdot \frac{1}{6} + 4 \cdot \frac{1}{6} + 5 \cdot \frac{1}{6} + 6 \cdot \frac{1}{6} \\
&= \frac{1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + 5 + 6}{6} \\
&= \frac{21}{6} = 3.5
\end{aligned}\]


Interpretation: If you rolled the die many times, the average would approach 3.5
Note: The expected value doesn‚Äôt have to be a possible outcome!

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Example: Unfair Die
Question 3: What if the die is not fair?



\(x\)
1
2
3
4
5
6




\(P(X=x)\)
1/9
1/9
1/9
1/9
2/9
3/9




\[\begin{aligned}
E(X) &= 1 ( \frac{1}{9}) + 2(\frac{1}{9}) + 3(\frac{1}{9}) + 4(\frac{1}{9}) + 5(\frac{2}{9}) + 6 (\frac{3}{9}) \\
&= (\frac{1 + 2 + 3 + 4}{9})  + (\frac{10}{9}) + (\frac{18}{9}) \\
&= (\frac{38}{9}) \\
&= 4.222 \dots
\end{aligned}\]


The die is ‚Äúloaded‚Äù toward higher values (mean is 4.22 vs.¬†3.5 for fair die)

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Variance and Standard Deviation
Just like with data, we measure spread with variance and standard deviation.



Definition: Variance of a Discrete R.V.


If \(X\) has expected value \(\mu = E(X)\), then:
\[\text{Var}(X) = \sigma^2 = \sum_{i=1}^k (x_i - \mu)^2 \cdot P(X=x_i)\]
The standard deviation is: \(SD(X) = \sigma = \sqrt{\text{Var}(X)}\)



Key idea: Squared deviations from the mean, weighted by probabilities

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
section: Example: Variance of a Fair Die
text:
Example: Variance of a Fair Die
We found \(E(X) = 3.5\). What is \(\text{Var}(X)\)?

\[\begin{aligned}
\text{Var}(X) &= \sum_{x=1}^6 (x - 3.5)^2 \cdot P(X=x) \\
&= (1-3.5)^2 \cdot \frac{1}{6} + (2-3.5)^2 \cdot \frac{1}{6} + \cdots + (6-3.5)^2 \cdot \frac{1}{6} \\
&= \frac{6.25 + 2.25 + 0.25 + 0.25 + 2.25 + 6.25}{6} \\
&= \frac{17.5}{6} \approx 2.92
\end{aligned}\]


Standard deviation: \(SD(X) = \sqrt{2.92} \approx 1.71\)

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Pause for a Quick Example
Apgar scores for newborns
Just after birth, each child is rated on the Apgar scale, with scores determined by color, heart rate, reflex irritability, muscle tone, and respiratory effort.


Let \(X\) = Apgar score. Historical data suggests the following probability distribution:

















\(x\)
0
1
2
3
4
5
6
7

9
10




\(P(X=x)\)
0.002
0.001
0.002
0.005
0.02
0.04
0.18
0.37
0.25
0.12
0.01





Questions:

What is \(E(X)\)?
What is \(\text{Var}(X)\)?

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Linear Combinations of Random Variables
Often in research, we combine multiple measurements into a composite score.



Definition: Linear Combination


If \(X\) and \(Y\) are random variables and \(a\) and \(b\) are constants:
\[aX + bY\]
is a linear combination of the random variables.



Examples in biomedical research:

Composite health scores (sum of multiple domains)
Weighted risk scores
Total costs (sum of different service types)

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Expected Value of Linear Combinations



Theorem: Expected Value of Linear Combinations


If \(X\) and \(Y\) are random variables and \(a\) and \(b\) are constants:
\[E(aX + bY) = aE(X) + bE(Y)\]
and
\[E(aX + b) = aE(X) + b\]



Key properties:

Expectation is linear - it distributes over addition
Works whether or not \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent
Constants factor out: \(E(cX) = cE(X)\)

This is intuitive: The average of a sum is the sum of the averages!

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Example: Clinical Trial Health Score (Setup)
In a clinical trial, researchers measure three patient-reported outcomes (PROs):

Pain score \((X_1)\): Scale 0-10, where 0 = no pain

\(E(X_1) = 4\), \(SD(X_1) = 2\)

Mobility score \((X_2)\): Scale 0-10, where 10 = full mobility

\(E(X_2) = 6\), \(SD(X_2) = 1.5\)

Quality of life score \((X_3)\): Scale 0-10, where 10 = excellent

\(E(X_3) = 5\), \(SD(X_3) = 2.5\)


A composite health score is calculated as: \[H = X_1 + X_2 + X_3\]
Assume the three scores are independent (one doesn‚Äôt influence the others).

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Example: Expected Composite Score
Question: What is the expected composite health score?

\[\begin{aligned}
E(H) &= E(X_1 + X_2 + X_3) \\
&= E(X_1) + E(X_2) + E(X_3) \\
&= 4 + 6 + 5 \\
&= 15
\end{aligned}\]


Interpretation: On average, patients have a composite health score of 15 out of 30.

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Variance of Linear Combinations



Theorem: Variance of Linear Combinations


If \(X\) and \(Y\) are INDEPENDENT random variables and \(a\) and \(b\) are constants:
\[\mathrm{Var}(aX + bY) = a^2\mathrm{Var}(X) + b^2\mathrm{Var}(Y)\]






General formula when not independent


The general formula is
\[\mathrm{Var}(aX + bY) = a^2\mathrm{Var}(X) + b^2\mathrm{Var}(Y) + 2ab\, \mathrm{Cov}(X,Y)\] If independent, \(\mathrm{Cov}(X,Y) = 0\).



The standard deviation is the square root of the variance.

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Example: Variance of Composite Score
Question: What is the variance and standard deviation of the composite health score?
Recall: \(H = X_1 + X_2 + X_3\)

\(\text{Var}(X_1) = 2^2 = 4\)
\(\text{Var}(X_2) = 1.5^2 = 2.25\)

\(\text{Var}(X_3) = 2.5^2 = 6.25\)


\[\begin{aligned}
\text{Var}(H) &= \text{Var}(X_1 + X_2 + X_3) \\
&= \text{Var}(X_1) + \text{Var}(X_2) + \text{Var}(X_3) \\
&= 4 + 2.25 + 6.25 \\
&= 12.5
\end{aligned}\]


\[SD(H) = \sqrt{12.5} \approx 3.54\]

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Example: Weighted Composite Score
Now suppose researchers want to weight the scores differently:
\[H_{\text{weighted}} = 0.5X_1 + 0.3X_2 + 0.2X_3\]

Weights sum to 1, so this is a weighted average (0-10 scale), not a total score.
Gives more weight to pain and mobility than quality of life.



Questions:

What is \(E(H_{\text{weighted}})\)?
What is \(\text{Var}(H_{\text{weighted}})\)?

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Solution: Weighted Composite Score
1. Expected value:
\[\begin{aligned}
E(H_{\text{weighted}}) &= E(0.5X_1 + 0.3X_2 + 0.2X_3) \\
&= 0.5E(X_1) + 0.3E(X_2) + 0.2E(X_3) \\
&= 0.5(4) + 0.3(6) + 0.2(5) \\
&= 2 + 1.8 + 1.0 \\
&= 4.8
\end{aligned}\]

2. Variance:
\[\begin{aligned}
\text{Var}(H_{\text{weighted}}) &= (0.5)^2\text{Var}(X_1) + (0.3)^2\text{Var}(X_2) + (0.2)^2\text{Var}(X_3) \\
&= 0.25(4) + 0.09(2.25) + 0.04(6.25) \\
&= 1.0 + 0.20 + 0.25 \\
&= 1.45
\end{aligned}\]
\[SD(H_{\text{weighted}}) = \sqrt{1.45} \approx 1.20\]

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Key Takeaways: Linear Combinations
Expected value: \[E(aX + bY) = aE(X) + bE(Y)\]

Linear property
No independence needed
Constants factor out

Variance: \[\text{Var}(aX + bY) = a^2\text{Var}(X) + b^2\text{Var}(Y)\]

Requires independence
Constants are squared
Standard deviations don‚Äôt simply add



Why this matters: Many biomedical measures are composite scores!

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Binary Outcomes
Many situations involve two possible outcomes:

Flipping a coin: heads or tails
Medical test: positive or negative

Surgery outcome: success or failure
Manufacturing: defective or non-defective

We call these binary or Bernoulli trials:

One outcome is called a ‚Äúsuccess‚Äù (probability \(p\))
The other is called a ‚Äúfailure‚Äù (probability \(q = 1-p\))

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Bernoulli Distribution



Definition: Bernoulli Random Variable


If \(X\) is a random variable that takes:

Value 1 with probability \(p\) (success)
Value 0 with probability \(1-p\) (failure)

Then \(X\) is a Bernoulli random variable.
Notation: \(X \sim \text{Bernoulli}(p)\) or \(X \sim \text{Bern}(p)\)



Parameter: \(p\) is the probability of success (between 0 and 1)

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Bernoulli: Mean and Variance



Theorem: Mean and Variance of Bernoulli R.V.


If \(X \sim \text{Bernoulli}(p)\), then:
\[E(X) = p\] \[\text{Var}(X) = p(1-p)\]



Example with diabetes:

Among US adults aged 65-74, about 20.3% have diabetes
Define \(X = 1\) if a randomly selected adult has diabetes, \(X = 0\) otherwise
\(E(X) = 0.203\)
\(\text{Var}(X) = 0.203(0.797) = 0.162\)

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
From Bernoulli to Binomial
What if we repeat a Bernoulli trial multiple times?
Example: Randomly select 10 adults aged 65-74. How many have diabetes?

Each person: Bernoulli(0.203)
Total number with diabetes: Binomial(10, 0.203)




Key Relationship


\[\text{Binomial}(n, p) = \text{Sum of } n \text{ independent Bernoulli}(p) \text{ trials}\]

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
From Bernoulli to Binomial (continued)

The Bernoulli distribution is a special case of the Binomial distribution where \(n=1\)

Specifically: \[\text{Binomial}(1, p) = \text{Bernoulli}(p) \]

To get a Binomial distribution, we simply extend the scenario from a single trial to multiple independent trials.

If we conduct \(n\) independent Bernoulli trials with the same success probability \(p\), the total number of successes across these \(n\) trials will follow a Binomial distribution

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Binomial Distribution: Definition



Definition: Binomial Random Variable


\(X\) is a Binomial random variable if:

There are \(n\) independent trials
Each trial has two outcomes: success or failure
Probability of success is \(p\) (same for all trials)
\(X\) counts the total number of successes

Notation: \(X \sim \text{Binomial}(n, p)\) or \(X \sim \text{Binom}(n, p)\)



Parameters: \(n\) (number of trials) and \(p\) (probability of success)
Possible values: \(X \in \{0, 1, 2, \ldots, n\}\)

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
section: When NOT to Use a Binomial Model
text:
When NOT to Use a Binomial Model



Common Pitfalls


A Binomial model is NOT appropriate when:

Trials are not independent

Example: sampling without replacement from a small population
(Probabilities change after each draw)

Probability of success is not constant

Example: different subjects have different risk levels
(\(p\) varies across trials)





Rule of thumb: If independence or constant \(p\) is violated ‚Üí not Binomial

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Derivation by example
Approximately 20.3% of US adults aged 65-74 have diabetes.
Here, let‚Äôs define

‚ÄúSuccess‚Äù (S) to be the event that a person has diabetes, then
‚ÄúFailure‚Äù (F) is the event that a person does not have diabetes.

Among US adults aged 65-74:

\(P(\text{has diabetes}) = 0.203 = p\)
\(P(\text{no diabetes}) = 1 - p = 0.797\)

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Define an experiment
Suppose we conduct an experiment in which \(n = 3\) US adults aged 65-74 are tested for diabetes.

The testing of each adult represents a trial.
The outcome from each trial is either a success (has diabetes) or a failure (does not have diabetes).
The outcome (S/F) of any one trial is not influenced by earlier outcomes nor does it affect later outcomes (independent trials).
The probability of having diabetes (\(p = 0.203\)) is the same for each adult sampled.

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Possible outcomes
With 3 trials and 2 possible outcomes (S/F), there are 8 possible arrangements.



\(FFF\)
\(FSS\)


\(FFS\)
\(SFS\)


\(FSF\)
\(SSF\)


\(SFF\)
\(SSS\)

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Define the rv
Let \(X =\) the number of adults that have diabetes among the \(n = 3\) sampled.


Re-organize the possible arrangements:

\(X = 0 \Longleftrightarrow FFF\)
\(X = 1 \Longleftrightarrow FFS \cup FSF \cup SFF\)
\(X = 2 \Longleftrightarrow FSS \cup SFS \cup SSF\)
\(X = 3 \Longleftrightarrow SSS\)

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Compute the probabilities


Case: \(X = 0\) (no one has diabetes)
\[\begin{aligned}
P(X = 0) &= P(FFF) \\
&\overset{\text{ind.}}{=} (1 - p)(1 - p)(1 - p) \\
&= (1 - p)^3 = 0.797^3 \approx 0.506
\end{aligned}\]
Because of the general multiplication rule for independent events, we simplified the event \(FFF\) into the product of \(n = 3\) separate terms.

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Compute the probabilities (continued)


Case: \(X = 1\) (exactly 1 has diabetes)

\(FFS \Longrightarrow (1 - p)(1 - p)p = p(1 - p)^2\)
\(FSF \Longrightarrow (1 - p)p(1 - p) = p(1 - p)^2\)
\(SFF \Longrightarrow p(1 - p)(1 - p) = p(1 - p)^2\)



Substitute for \(p\) and \((1-p)\) then for each \(p(1 - p)^2 = (0.203)(0.797)^2 \approx 0.129\).


\[\begin{aligned}
P(X = 1) &= P(FFS \cup FSF \cup SFF) \\
&= P(FFS) + P(FSF) + P(SFF) \\
&= 3p(1 - p)^2 \approx 3(0.129) = 0.387
\end{aligned}\]

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Compute the probabilities (continued)


Case: \(X = 2\) (exactly 2 have diabetes)
Similar reasoning gives

\(FSS \Longrightarrow (1 - p)pp = p^2(1 - p)\)
\(SFS \Longrightarrow p(1 - p)p = p^2(1 - p)\)
\(SSF \Longrightarrow pp(1 - p) = p^2(1 - p)\)



Each of the three parts is approximately \(0.033\)


\[\begin{aligned}
P(X = 2) &= P(FSS \cup SFS \cup SSF) \\
&= P(FSS) + P(SFS) + P(SSF) \\
&= 3p^2(1 - p) \approx 3(0.033) = 0.099
\end{aligned}\]

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Compute the probabilities (continued)


Case: \(X = 3\) (all 3 have diabetes)
\[\begin{aligned}
P(X = 3) &= P(SSS) \\
&= ppp \\
&= p^3 = (0.203)^3 \approx 0.008
\end{aligned}\]

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
The Pattern Emerges
Looking at our calculations:



\(X\)
Number of arrangements
Probability




0
1
\(1 \times (0.203)^0(0.797)^3 = 0.506\)


1
3
\(3 \times (0.203)^1(0.797)^2 = 0.387\)


2
3
\(3 \times (0.203)^2(0.797)^1 = 0.099\)


3
1
\(1 \times (0.203)^3(0.797)^0 = 0.008\)




Pattern: \[P(X = k) = (\text{number of arrangements}) \times p^k(1-p)^{n-k}\]
Question: How do we count the number of arrangements for any \(n\) and \(k\)?

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Counting Arrangements: ‚Äún choose k‚Äù
The number of ways to arrange \(k\) successes among \(n\) trials is:
\[\binom{n}{k} = \frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!}\]
This is called the binomial coefficient or ‚Äún choose k‚Äù
Reminder: \(n!\) (read ‚Äún factorial‚Äù) means \(n \times (n-1) \times (n-2) \times \cdots \times 2 \times 1\)

Example: \(3! = 3 \times 2 \times 1 = 6\)
Special case: \(0! = 1\) (by definition)


For our example with \(n=3\):

\(\binom{3}{0} = \frac{3!}{0!3!} = \frac{6}{1 \times 6} = 1\) ‚úì
\(\binom{3}{1} = \frac{3!}{1!2!} = \frac{6}{1 \times 2} = 3\) ‚úì
\(\binom{3}{2} = \frac{3!}{2!1!} = \frac{6}{2 \times 1} = 3\) ‚úì
\(\binom{3}{3} = \frac{3!}{3!0!} = \frac{6}{6 \times 1} = 1\) ‚úì

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Binomial distribution
The final rule is



Distribution of a Binomial random variable


Let \(X\) be the total number of successes in \(n\) independent trials, each with probability \(p\) of a success. Then probability of observing exactly \(k\) successes in \(n\) independent trials is
\[P(X = k) = \binom{n}{k} p^k (1-p)^{n-k},  k= 0, 1, 2, \dots, n \]



Components:

\(\binom{n}{k}\): number of ways to arrange \(k\) successes in \(n\) trials
\(p^k\): probability of \(k\) successes
\((1-p)^{n-k}\): probability of \(n-k\) failures

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Verify with our example
Does our formula work for \(n=3, p=0.203\)?
\[P(X = k) = \binom{n}{k} p^k (1-p)^{n-k}\]




\(k\)
Formula
Probability




0
\(\binom{3}{0} (0.203)^0(0.797)^3\)
0.506


1
\(\binom{3}{1} (0.203)^1(0.797)^2\)
0.387


2
\(\binom{3}{2} (0.203)^2(0.797)^1\)
0.099


3
\(\binom{3}{3} (0.203)^3(0.797)^0\)
0.008





Matches what we calculated by hand! ‚úì

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Now extend to 10 adults
Now we can easily calculate probabilities for \(n=10\) adults:
Setup: \(X \sim \text{Binomial}(n=10, p=0.203)\)


Without the formula: We‚Äôd need to enumerate \(2^{10} = 1024\) possible arrangements!


With the formula: We can calculate any probability directly:
\[P(X = 4) = \binom{10}{4} (0.203)^4 (0.797)^6 = \frac{10!}{4!6!} (0.203)^4 (0.797)^6 \approx 0.091\]


The binomial formula saves us from tedious counting!

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
R Makes This Even Easier!


We can also use R to calculate binomial probabilities:

# Verify our n=3 calculations
dbinom(x = 0:3, size = 3, prob = 0.203)

[1] 0.506261573 0.386842281 0.098530719 0.008365427





# Calculate P(X = 4) for n=10
dbinom(x = 4, size = 10, prob = 0.203)

[1] 0.09140151


¬†
This is especially helpful when you need many probabilities or when \(n\) is large!

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Binomial: Mean and Variance



Theorem: Mean and Variance of Binomial R.V.


If \(X \sim \text{Binomial}(n, p)\), then:
\[E(X) = np\] \[\text{Var}(X) = np(1-p)\] \[SD(X) = \sqrt{np(1-p)}\]



Intuition:

If each trial has probability \(p\) of success, and we do \(n\) trials, we expect \(np\) successes on average
The variance formula comes from summing \(n\) independent Bernoulli variances

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
section: Example: Diabetes in Older Adults (10 people)
text:
Example: Diabetes in Older Adults (10 people)


Approximately 20.3% of US adults aged 65-74 have diabetes. Suppose we randomly select 10 adults in this age group (independently).


Let \(X\) = number with diabetes among the 10 people
Setup: \(X \sim \text{Binomial}(n=10, p=0.203)\)



Question 1: What is the expected value of \(X\)?
\[E(X) = np = 10(0.203) = 2.03\]




Question 2: What is the standard deviation of \(X\)?
\[SD(X) = \sqrt{np(1-p)} = \sqrt{10(0.203)(0.797)} = \sqrt{1.618} \approx 1.27\]

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Example: Exactly 4 with Diabetes
Question 3: What is the probability that exactly 4 of the 10 have diabetes?
\[P(X = 4) = \binom{10}{4} (0.203)^4 (0.797)^6\]

\[= \frac{10!}{4! \cdot 6!} (0.203)^4 (0.797)^6 = 210 \times 0.0017 \times 0.256 \approx 0.091\]


In R:

dbinom(x = 4, size = 10, prob = 0.203)

[1] 0.09140151





dbinom gives the pmf: \(P(X = x)\) for a discrete distribution. (probability at a specific value)
R uses ‚Äúd‚Äù for these functions to stand for ‚Äúdensity‚Äù; for discrete distributions it returns the probability mass.

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Example: At Most 3 with Diabetes
Question 4: What is the probability that at most 3 have diabetes?
\[P(X \leq 3) = P(X=0) + P(X=1) + P(X=2) + P(X=3)\]

We could calculate each term, but there‚Äôs an easier way!




In R:

pbinom(q = 3, size = 10, prob = 0.203)

[1] 0.8737821




The p in pbinom stands for ‚Äúcumulative probability‚Äù, \(P(X \leq k)\)


Result: About 87% chance that 3 or fewer have diabetes

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Example: At Least 5 with Diabetes
Question 5: What is the probability that at least 5 have diabetes?
\[P(X \geq 5) = P(X=5) + P(X=6) + \cdots + P(X=10)\]

Approach 1: Use complement rule \[P(X \geq 5) = 1 - P(X \leq 4)\]

1 - pbinom(q = 4, size = 10, prob = 0.203)

[1] 0.03481642






Approach 2: Use lower.tail = FALSE

pbinom(q = 4, size = 10, prob = 0.203, lower.tail = FALSE)

[1] 0.03481642


Result: About 3.4% chance that 5 or more have diabetes

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
R Functions for Binomial Distribution










Function
What it does
Example




dbinom()
Probability at specific value: \(P(X=k)\)
dbinom(x = 4, size = 10, prob = 0.203)


pbinom()
Cumulative probability: \(P(X \leq k)\)
pbinom(q = 3, size = 10, prob = 0.203)


qbinom()
Quantile: Find \(k\) for given probability
qbinom(p = 0.5, size = 10, prob = 0.203)


rbinom()
Generate random samples
rbinom(n = 100, size = 10, prob = 0.203)

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text: Visualizing the Binomial Distribution

title: Random Variables and Binomial Distribution
text:
Key Takeaways
Random Variables:

Connect random outcomes to numerical values and probabilities
Expected value: weighted average using probabilities
Variance: measures spread around the expected value
Linear combinations: \(E(aX+bY) = aE(X) + bE(Y)\), but \(\text{Var}(aX+bY) = a^2\text{Var}(X) + b^2\text{Var}(Y)\) (if independent)

Binomial Distribution:

Models number of successes in \(n\) independent trials
Parameters: \(n\) (trials) and \(p\) (success probability)
\(E(X) = np\), \(\text{Var}(X) = np(1-p)\)
Use R functions: dbinom(), pbinom(), etc.
